In Stage 2, set the price of the item the buyer initially chose (Apple) slightly lower than the alternative (Orange) to encourage the buyer to stick with their initial choice. For example, set the Apple price at 4 and the Orange price at 6. This increases the likelihood of the buyer choosing the Apple again in Stage 3, maximizing your utility by receiving a higher price for the chosen item.

In Stage 2, set the price of the item the buyer initially chose (Apple) higher than the alternative (Orange) to encourage the buyer to switch to the higher-priced item. For example, set the Apple price at 6 and the Orange price at 4. This increases the likelihood of the buyer choosing the Orange in Stage 3, maximizing your utility by receiving a higher price for the chosen item.

This strategy maximizes your utility by receiving a higher price for the chosen item. No different pricing would have resulted in higher utility, as the buyer is equally likely to switch or stay with their initial choice.
